SEARCH
Module iu.util.type
Package edu.iu.type

Interface IuType<D,T>

Type Parameters:
D - declaring type, nullable
T - described generic type
All Superinterfaces:
IuAnnotatedElement, IuDeclaredElement<D>, IuNamedElement<D>, IuParameterizedElement
All Known Implementing Classes:
TypeFacade, TypeTemplate
public interface IuType<D,T> extends IuNamedElement<D>, IuParameterizedElement
Facade interface for a generic type.

IuType is sterotyped as a hash key, so may be used as the key value with WeakHashMap to build type-level extensions from specific generic type scenarios. For example IuType has a 1:1 relationship with Class, but a separate 1:1 with a Classes referred to via specific TypeVariable, ParameterizedType, GenericArrayType, or WildcardType.

The hash key stereotype is implemented by of(Class) and of(Type), and is only implied by implementations provided by those methods.

Private Erasure

This interface exposes all declared field and method members from all types in decorated type's hierarchy in additional to those declared directly on its type erasure. That includes private members of superclasses. The purpose of this utility is to find fields and bean properties on well-formed application classes that may or may not be annotated as container-managed associations. The container therefore uses IuType to access privately scoped members and populate those associations.

It is the application developer's responsibility to ensure that private members only shadow same-named private members in a super class when it is intended for the subclass to use its member instead of any inherited shadowed member of the same name. For example, when using @AroundInvoke to define interceptor methods intended to be inherited from a superclass, use a name reasonably unique to the declaring class. This scenario mirrors method override behavior, but fields may be shadowed and continue to exist as separate private fields with the same name but potentially different type and value.

Private erasure is relevant for deserialization, remote service discovery, and method invocation. Other scenarios, i.e., dependency injection, should iterate all members unless a specific name is provided.

  • Method Details

    • of

      static IuType<?,?> of(Type type)
      Resolves a type introspection facade for a generic type.
      Parameters:
      type - generic type
      Returns:
      type introspection facade

    • of

      static <T> IuType<?,T> of(Class<T> rawClass)
      Resolves a type introspection facade for a class.

      An introspection facade returned by this method must:

      • Be final and immutable.
      • Have 1:1 parity with Class instances, such that IuType.of(MyClass.class) == IuType.of(MyClass.class) returns for all classes.

      All use of this method and subsequent type introspection lookups must thread-safe.

      Type Parameters:
      T - type
      Parameters:
      rawClass - type
      Returns:
      type introspection facade

    • reference

      IuTypeReference<T,?> reference()
      Gets the reference used to obtain this type.
      Returns:
      type reference

      Gets the generic type.
      Returns:

    • erasedClass

      default Class<T> erasedClass()
      Get the type erasure class.

      Shorthand for erase().deref()

      Returns:
      type erasure class
      See Also:
      • erase()
      • JLS 21 Section 4.4: Type Erasure

    • autoboxClass

      default Class<T> autoboxClass()
      Returns the autobox equivalent
      Returns:
      the object version related to a primitive type, or the class passed in as-is if not primitive

    • autoboxDefault

      default T autoboxDefault()
      Returns the default value for an object or primitive type.
      Returns:
      The default value that would be assigned to a field of described primitive type if declared without an initializer; null if the described time is not primitive.

    • erase

      IuType<D,T> erase()
      Gets the erased facade, which describing the Class representing the erasure of the generic type.

      The deref() of the erased facade must return a Class.

      Returns:
      erased type facade
      See Also:
      • JLS 21 Section 4.4: Type Erasure

    • sub

      default <S> IuType<D,? extends S> sub(Class<S> subclass) throws ClassCastException
      Gets a type-enforced facade for a specific sub-type of the described type.
      Type Parameters:
      S - sub-type
      Parameters:
      subclass - subclass of the described type
      Returns:
      this
      Throws:
      ClassCastException - If the type does not erase to a subclass

    • hierarchy

      Iterable<? extends IuType<?,? super T>> hierarchy()
      Iterates the type hierarchy, from most specific to least specific.
      1. All Class.getGenericInterfaces()
      2. Class.getGenericSuperclass()
      3. Iterate hierarchy() until Object is reached

      This type described by this facade is not included. Object is always the last element.

      Returns:
      inherited and extended types

    • referTo

      IuType<?,? super T> referTo(Type referentType)
      Refers to a type in the the described type's hierarchy.

      When the referent type declares type parameters, the resolved generic types associated with those parameters are described by the returned facade.

      Parameters:
      referentType - type to refer to
      Returns:
      referent facade

    • fields

      Iterable<? extends IuField<? super T,?>> fields()
      Gets all fields defined by this type, followed by all fields defined by all types in this type's hierarchy, in hierarchy() order.
      Returns:
      fields declared by this type and its hierarchy, in this followed by hierarchy() order

    • field

      default <F> IuField<? super T,F> field(String name)
      Gets a field declared by this type.

      When a private field has the same name as a different field declared by a super class, the "inherited" field is shadowed by this method. To retrieve all fields, including those shadowed by a superclass, use fields().

      Type Parameters:
      F - field type
      Parameters:
      name - field name
      Returns:
      field

    • annotatedFields

      default Iterable<? extends IuField<? super T,?>> annotatedFields(Class<? extends Annotation> annotationType)
      Scans fields for those annotated with a specific annotation type.
      Parameters:
      annotationType - annotation type to filter by
      Returns:
      fields(), filtered by annotation type

    • methods

      Iterable<? extends IuMethod<? super T,?>> methods()
      Gets all methods defined by this type.

      The result iterates all methods declared on all classes in the type erasure's hierarchy with private erasure for duplicately defined methods.

      Returns:
      methods

    • observe

      void observe(T instance)
      Observes a new instance.

      Observing an instance registers it with the implementation module as an available target for type introspection, for example, for resource binding. Implementors of InstanceReference may use subscribe(InstanceReference) to be notified when new instances are observed.

      Once all InstanceReferences have been notified, all methods annotated by @PostConstruct will be invoked on the instance.

      Observing an instance that is already observed has no effect, nor does observing an instance of a type that has no subscribers. All instances provided via IuExecutable.exec(Object...) are observed automatically. This method is a no-op for those instances, however it is up to implementors to ensure @PostConstruct methods do not result in errors or repeat initialization steps when invoked repeatedly.

      Parameters:
      instance - to observe

    • destroy

      void destroy(T instance)
      Destroys an instance.

      Invokes all @PreDestroy methods on an instance. If the instance was observed, its state will be reverted and no futures actions will be taken on it.

      This method may be invoked to close the lifecycle of instances created via IuExecutable.exec(Object...).

      Destroying an instance that is already destroyed should have no effect, but it is up to implementors to ensure @PreDestroy methods do not result in errors or other side-effects when invoked repeatedly.

      Parameters:
      instance - to destroy

    • subscribe

      Runnable subscribe(InstanceReference<T> instanceReference)
      Subscribes a new instance reference.
      Parameters:
      instanceReference - will accept all observed instances until unsubscribed.
      Returns:
      thunk for unsubscribing the reference
